author: Patrick Wilson
title: Virginia ethics council holds first meeting
text:
RICHMOND Another state panel? Sounds tedious, but the issue is one that’s been in Virginia’s political forefront: the ethics of politicians.
The Virginia Conflict of Interest and Ethics Advisory Council was created in reform legislation this year that was signed by Gov. Terry McAuliffe in April. The panel stems from the corruption conviction of former Gov. Bob McDonnell. It met for the first time Monday to review its duties.
The nine-member body includes four lawmakers, which subjected the General Assembly to complaints that it didn’t go far enough toward creating an independent group. McAuliffe and a study commission he formed that is chaired by former Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling, a Republican, and former U.S. Rep. Rick Boucher, a Democrat, have called for an independent ethics commission.
The panel chose retired Court of Appeals Chief Judge Walter Felton as chairman.
Lawmakers on the panel are Sen. Tommy Norment, R-James City County; Del. Todd Gilbert, R-Shenandoah County; Sen. Janet Howell, D-Fairfax County; and Del. Jennifer McClellan, D-Richmond.
The panel will issue formal and informal advice on ethics issues. Formal opinions will be published online. Informal advice will be kept secret and treated similarly to information protected by attorney-client privilege.
Other duties of the panel will be approving certain travel for lawmakers and creating a searchable database with information from lawmakers’ financial disclosure forms.
Lawmakers are required to file those forms twice a year, in June and December.
The council will meet again this year at a date not yet set and must issue an annual report on its activities by Dec. 1 to the General Assembly and governor.
“There’s a lot of moving parts. This is brand new,” said Chris Piper, the council’s executive director. “There’s a lot of things that we’re all trying to figure out.”
Piper said he expects the council will receive a high volume of questions.
Dale Eisman, spokesman for D.C.-based Common Cause, which lobbies to remove the influence of money in politics, said Virginia needs an ethics commission independent of lawmakers that can investigate and audit books of candidates and campaign committees
“It will take more than an ‘advisory council’ to remove the stain on Virginia’s reputation for good government left by the conviction of former Gov. McDonnell,” he said.
He also said the General Assembly should ban corporate campaign donations and impose limits on other campaign donations. Virginia is one of the few states in the nation with no cap.
McDonnell was sentenced in January to two years in prison following convictions last year in a corruption case. He remains free while his case is on appeal before the U.S. Supreme Court. His wife, Maureen McDonnell, also was convicted and remains free on appeal.
